Thrips palmi, also known as the melon thrips or yellow tea thrips, is a species of thrips that belongs to the order Thysanoptera. It is considered a significant agricultural pest, particularly affecting crops such as melons, cucumbers, peppers, and other vegetables.

The adult Thrips palmi is small, measuring around 1-1.5 millimeters in length. It has a yellowish-brown or pale yellow body and narrow, fringed wings. The larvae are also yellowish-white in color and resemble the adults, but without fully developed wings.

Thrips palmi is native to Southeast Asia but has spread to various parts of the world, including the Americas, Europe, and Africa, primarily through the international trade of infested plant material. The species reproduces rapidly, with a life cycle that can be completed in as little as 2-3 weeks under favorable conditions.

The damage caused by Thrips palmi is primarily due to their feeding habits. They use their piercing-sucking mouthparts to extract plant fluids, leading to the development of characteristic silvery or whitish scars on the leaves, flowers, and fruits of the infested plants. This feeding damage can significantly reduce crop yields and quality.

Thrips palmi is considered a quarantine pest in many countries, and efforts are made to prevent its introduction and spread through strict phytosanitary measures and integrated pest management strategies, including the use of biological control agents and the application of selective insecticides.
